questions.question: Can you get some sugar from the shop? We have run ………………
questions.description: To run out of something is to have none of it left.

questions.question: This car runs ……………… petrol.
questions.description: When a car runs on petrol, it is powered by petrol.

questions.question: The boy ran …………….. from home because he had no one to love him there.
questions.description: To run away is to escape or to run from somebody who is chasing you.

questions.question: Cancer runs ……………. his family. Both his parents died of it.
questions.description: If a disease runs in a family, it is kind of hereditary.

questions.question: The police constable ran ………………. the thief but he could not catch him.
questions.description: To run after somebody is to chase them.

questions.question: When we were kids we would spend the entire afternoon running ……………. the neighborhood.
I want to run ……………… President.
questions.description: To run for President is to try to be elected President.

questions.question: I ran …………….. an old friend of mine yesterday.
questions.description: To run into somebody is to meet them unexpectedly.

questions.question: Can you run ………………. hundred copies of this document?
questions.description: Run off can mean make photocopies.

questions.question: I ran ………………. a dog while driving home from work.
questions.description: To run over a dog is to hit it with a vehicle.

questions.question: He has run ……………… a huge debt on his credit cards.
questions.description: To run up debt is to spend a lot of money on credit.

questions.question: He ran ………………. the presentation one more time to ensure that everything is perfect.
questions.description: To run through a presentation is to practice it quickly.
